results.title: The Last days of disco [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Whit Stillman, Westerly Films and Castle Rock
results.brief_description: It is the very early 1980s. Alice (Chloe Sevigny) and Charlotte (Kate Beckinsale) are two ambitious publishing assistants who transform themselves into glamourous disco queens and spend their nights dancing at The Club. That is until their disco-world is turned upside down by a seemingly bisexual lothario, Des (Chris Eigeman), whose involvement with drugs lands him and his money-siphoning friends in trouble with the law. A hilarious tale of tangled romances, friendship and music you just can’t stop dancing to!

results.title: The Last days of Chez Nous
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Jan Chapman and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description: Beth (Lisa Harrow) is a successful novelist who runs her career and inner-city household, “Chez Nous” with great energy and humour, despite her hectic life with her French husband (Bruno Ganz), her carefree teenage daughter (Miranda Otto) and a new boarder (Kiri Paramore). The return of her younger sister, Vicky (Kerry Fox) sparks a chain of events which escalate in the intense heat of an Australian Summer and could spell the last days of “Chez Nous”. Also stars Bill Hunter.

results.title: The Last days
results.creator_credit: James Moll, Ken Lipper, June Beallor, Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation and Steven Spielberg
results.brief_description: In late 1944, at great cost while Germany was losing the war, Hitler brought the Holocaust to Hungary. In one of the last centers of Jewish culture, the Nazis deported and killed 425,000 people in just sixty days. This documentary is a moving and compelling account of five Hungarian survivors, tracing their lives from the present, back to the “cleansing” of Hungary and the devastation of the concentration camps. It is an outgrowth of the Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation. Created by Steven Spielberg in 1994 after he filmed ‘Schindler’s List’, the organization is dedicated to recording the oral histories of as many Holocaust survivors as possible before they die. Music by Hans Zimmer.

results.title: The Last Crop
results.creator_credit: Sue Clayton, Billy MacKinnon, Channel Four, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Film Commission, Film Australia and Zenith
results.brief_description: Ann cleans for a living. She shares everything she has with her two moody children and her equally erratic neighbours but she also shares everything her rich and constantly out-of-town employers have. When Ann’s not sorting out the lives of her family and friends, she’s thinking about her father’s property in the country and how nice it would be to live there. Only one little international mining company stands in her way. But Ann, used to beating the system in her own quiet way, is not about to let that spoil her plans. The dry, quirky style of this wonderfully honest film portrays Australian life in a refreshingly unfashionable way. Based on the short story by Elizabeth Jolley.

results.title: The Last bus home
results.creator_credit: Johnny Gogan, Paul Donovan and Bandit Films Ltd
results.brief_description: Dublin forms the backdrop of this evocative film about friendship, punk music, secrets, sexuality, and Dublin in the late 70’s and early 80’s. Punks Reena (Annie Ryan) and Jessop (Brian O’Byrne) meet on the day the Pope comes to Dublin. They form an instant alliance both physically and musically, and together with bassist Joe (Barry Comerford) and drummer Petie (John Cronin), begin 3 years of work to gain recognition for their band; The Dead Patriots. Tensions rise personally, with repercussions professionally as one feeds off the other. The situation reaches a head when Jessop discovers a secret and makes his feelings known at the band’s final farewell gig. 10 years pass and the members re-unite for a final confrontation and re-unification. Cast also includes Anthony Brophy, Brendan Coyle and Donal O’Kelly.

results.title: The Last Bolshevik
results.creator_credit: Chris Marker, Michael Kustow and Channel 4
results.brief_description: Chris Marker, the acclaimed director of “Sunless” is one of the cinema’s most compelling documentary film-makers. This engrossing film is firstly a tribute to Alexander Medvedkin, a Soviet film-maker and revolutionary, who eventually to fell victim to Stalin’s infamous purges. “The Last Bolshevik”, framed around six imaginary letters to Medvedkin by Marker, is also a mediation on the history of Soviet communism and a critical examination of revolutionary aesthetics. Marker was a central figure in the French New Wave and was involved in rehabilitating Medvedkin’s career in the late-1960s. It is then also a personal self-appraisal of the artist’s own politics and aesthetics, an appraisal which aims to investigate what drew artists to the radicalism of Soviet Bolshevism and the consequences for “radical art” now that Communism has been discredited. The film not only explores Medvedkin’s work but also the cinema of Eisenstein and Dziga-Vertov. A documentary that assumes intelligence and philosophical eruditness from its audience is rare indeed. This melancholy farewell to the dream of “creating utopia” is a wonderful film.

results.title: The Last bastion
results.creator_credit: Chris Thomson, Brian Rosen and Network Ten (Australia)
results.brief_description: Set in Australia in 1942 and concerning the threat of Japanese invasion, this is a drama about the characters and events of the time in Australian history in which the inner cabinet of Australia’s coalition war government played a major role. The distinguished cast includes Timothy West, Robert Vaughn, John Wood, Michael Blakemore, Warren Mitchell and Ray Barrett. David Williamson co-wrote the script.

results.title: The Laser beam
results.creator_credit: Leo A. Handel and Handel Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Uses animation to explain the principle of the laser. Shows some of the applications of lasers in medicine, industry, communications, space exploration and the holograms that may lead to three-dimensional television. Traces the history of lasers and shows how emission spectra and lasers are related. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Language of maps
results.brief_description: Uses aerial photography, topographic models and maps to show that the language of maps is composed of symbols representing natural and man-made features of the earth’s surface.
